content.description: Sit start on two opposing sloper features. The right-hand hold is slightly better than the left. Pull onto the wall with some obscure feet and power up to the jug at the lip or figure out how to use some very small and sharp intermediates before a desperate bump to the same jug. Once on the jug figure out how to top out with ease.
content.location: This problem is on the South-face of the boulder. The landing is a slight hill but not extreme. This problem starts a few feet left of the right-leaning arete on the triangular-shaped sloping features.

content.description: Stand start compressing the slab with a good left hand undercling and right hand side pull. Some trickery and balance a little higher off the deck makes this line a classic one in my eyes but the landing might deter some.
content.protection: 2-3 pads and spotter is recommended, there are a few trees only a couple feet back from the landing and it’s not very flat.
content.location: The slab that faces down hill on the dead-birch boulder

content.description: Sit start with a right hand pinch on the arete and left on a decent crimp. Pull on and you’re immediately into the Crux, after a right hand bump on the arete make a pretty big floating move out and left to a jug, a few more easy moves and you’ll be topping her out.
content.protection: 2 pads, pretty flat landing for being higher up on the hill!
content.location: The south side right arete of the dead-birch boulder

content.description: The Dead Birch Boulder is a fairly large boulder located uphill in the talus field. The East-face is very exposed with a slightly awkward but fairly good landing. While the South-face has a slightly slanted but clear landing. There are a few good problems on this boulder from a rad one-two clutch dyno to a hard compression slab leading to an exposed and very insecure top out over the downhill Eastside face of the boulder.
